channel.title: Context Engineering Daily - Chain-of-Thought
channel.description: Latest Chain-of-Thought news in Context Engineering

item.title: Large Language Models Naively Recover Ethnicity from Individual Records
item.description: arXiv:2601.21132v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: I demonstrate that large language models can infer ethnicity from names with accuracy exceeding that of Bayesian Improved Surname Geocoding (BISG) without additional training data, enabling inference outside the United States and to contextually appro...<br><br><small><strong>Source:</strong> arXiv | <strong>Keywords:</strong> model, GPT, arxiv, LLM, transformer | <strong>Relevance:</strong> 100%</small>
item.author: noreply@contextengineering.news (arXiv)

item.title: Teaching LLMs to Ask: Self-Querying Category-Theoretic Planning for Under-Specified Reasoning
item.description: arXiv:2601.20014v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Inference-time planning with large language models frequently breaks under partial observability: when task-critical preconditions are not specified at query time, models tend to hallucinate missing facts or produce plans that violate hard constraints...<br><br><small><strong>Source:</strong> arXiv | <strong>Keywords:</strong> model, arxiv, LLM, large language model, reasoning | <strong>Relevance:</strong> 100%</small>
item.author: noreply@contextengineering.news (arXiv)

item.title: Should I Have Expressed a Different Intent? Counterfactual Generation for LLM-Based Autonomous Control
item.description: arXiv:2601.20090v2 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language model (LLM)-powered agents can translate high-level user intents into plans and actions in an environment. Yet after observing an outcome, users may wonder: What if I had phrased my intent differently? We introduce a framework that enab...<br><br><small><strong>Source:</strong> arXiv | <strong>Keywords:</strong> framework, model, arxiv, RAG, LLM | <strong>Relevance:</strong> 100%</small>
item.author: noreply@contextengineering.news (arXiv)

item.title: ThinkSound - [NeurIPS 2025] PyTorch implementation of [ThinkSound], a unified framework for generating audio from any modality, guided by Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning.
